title: Synthesis Report on Laurent-Philippe Albou: Academic and Research Profile in Bioinformatics and Computational Biomedicine
key_findings: Laurent-Philippe Albou holds a PhD in bioinformatics and computational biology, having defended his doctoral thesis titled *Analyse intÃ©grative des donnÃ©es structurales et reconnaissance de forme : application Ã  la rÃ©gulation de la transcription eucaryote* at the University of Strasbourg on 29 September 2010.

His doctoral thesis was supervised by Dino Moras and Olivier Poch, both affiliated with the University of Strasbourg, confirming his academic affiliation with Unistra and institutional verification of his doctoral work.

Albou is a researcher profiled in multiple authoritative academic databases, including ORCID (0000-0001-5801-1974), Wikidata (Q90243383), AMiner, AD Scientific Index (ID 4443689), and dblp, which index his publications, co-authors, and research areas.
He has been cited 10,252 times in Google Scholar, with research interests in bioinformatics, genomics, drug discovery, machine learning, and semantics, indicating substantial scholarly impact.

Albou is currently a Scientific Project Manager in Computational Biomedicine at Roche, specifically at the Institut Roche for Research & Translational Medicine, with additional affiliations to the University of Southern California and Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory.
He is actively publishing in computer science and life sciences, with a structured publication list indexed in dblp from 2010 to present, supporting ongoing academic engagement.
His research profile includes technical certifications in AWS Solution Architecture and DevOps, indicating a blend of computational and data engineering expertise.
knowledge_gaps: No verified public information confirms the consistency of his professional roles across institutions over time.
No verifiable information found for: scholarly contributions
No direct evidence links his automotive lighting patent work to his academic bioinformatics research, despite separate mention of both.
The nature and scope of his role at Roche and institutional partnerships remain unspecified in the evidence provided.
No verifiable information found for: historiographical influence
There is no public record of his research output in automotive lighting, despite patent listings, nor verification of his current employment status.

summary: Laurent-Philippe Albou is a multidisciplinary researcher with a PhD in bioinformatics and computational biology, having completed his doctoral thesis at the University of Strasbourg in 2010. His research spans bioinformatics, genomics, machine learning, and computational biomedicine, with significant academic and institutional affiliations including Roche, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, and the University of Southern California. He is a published scholar with a strong academic footprint, as evidenced by citations, publication indexing, and formal researcher profiles across multiple databases.
